reviews.text: The opening hours of the campaign feel like a complete waste of time with boring and repetitive levels accompanied by a story that makes no sense.
The combat later on is a lot of fun and certain boss fights and quests have been great to test out new builds with.
The adaptive trigger support on PS5 for spectral attacks offering different resistance depending on your SP gauge and the attack is very nicely implemented.
The story makes no sense.
The final areas can look excellent with great boss battles even in the early parts.
Visual clarity issues in dark areas make it hard to identify certain things in some levels.
Voice acting is a mixed bag; some characters sound robotic.
The soundtrack is excellent, especially boss themes and area-specific songs.
The battle pass is always in your face with expensive cosmetics like NieR: Automata skins costing over $15.
Post-game modes like skirmishes and sieges are great but locked behind 15+ hours of play.
Visual glitches in cutscenes like flickering hair during important moments.
The game requires at least one co-op partner to be enjoyable.
The NieR: Automata collaboration event was quite excellent.
Early systems like gear enhancement and crafting are poorly explained.
The PS5 version has great haptic feedback and adaptive triggers.
Early gameplay feels like a long tutorial with no challenge until late game.
Combat customization options like attack modes and Gideon Coffin skills add depth.
The game's monetization feels like a free-to play game with premium cosmetics.
Boss fights with bullet hell patterns and arena designs are highlights.
Early levels with darkness and lantern mechanics are frustratingingly restrictive.
The game's core loop early on is a grind to progress through chapters.
The PS5 version's fast load times and haptic feedback are well-implemented.
